{{wikipedia|Makurakotoba}}

===Etymology===
Compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=まくらことば|枕|tr1=makura|t1=pillow|詞|tr2=kotoba|t2=word}}. The ''pillow'' meaning is in reference to the way that ''makura kotoba'' in poetry are used as introductions to something else.

===Pronunciation===
* {{l|ja|sc=Latn|訓読み|Kun'yomi}}
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[ma̠kɯᵝɺ̠a̠ ko̞to̞ba̠]}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|まくら ことば}}

# an [[epithet]], specifically a poetic device where a certain introductory phrase is commonly used to allude to something else, traditionally used in {{m|ja|和歌|tr=waka||traditional Japanese poetry}}
#: Over time, certain ''makura kotoba'' may become full [[metonym]]s to replace the term they originally only alluded to, such as the {{etyl|ojp|-}} phrase ''niwa tsu tori'' or “garden bird” replacing the older term ''kake'' to mean “chicken”, as in the modern Japanese term {{m|ja|鶏|tr=niwatori}}. An example of such a ''makura kotoba'':
#:: {{RQ:Kojiki|Kami tsu maki}}
#::: {{lang|ja|'''爾波都登理'''　迦祁波那久}}
#::: {{lang|ja|'''庭つ鳥'''　鶏は鳴く}}
#:::: {{lang|ja|'''にわつとり'''　かけはなく}}
#:::: '''''niwa tsu tori''', kake wa naku''
#::::: the '''garden bird''', the chicken clucks
